title: Aging With Pride: Innovations in Dementia Empowerment and Action
description_brief: The lack of efficacious research-based interventions for such vulnerable older adults with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (AD/RD) and their caregivers (CGs) is a significant public health problem. Caregiving of sexual/gender minority older adults with AD/RD is of concern due to social stigma, marginalization, and isolation, which may be barriers to sustaining caregiving. It is necessary and timely to translate evidence-based culturally adaptable interventions for this underserved and stigmatized population. Reducing Disability in Alzheimer's Disease (RDAD) has been evaluated in a randomized controlled trial and has shown to successfully train community-dwelling CR (care receiver)-CG dyads to increase the physical activity and functioning of individuals with AD/RD and their CGs and to teach CGs techniques for managing behavioral symptoms of CRs. RDAD consequently decreases stress of CGs, delays institutionalization of CRs, and increases health related quality of life (HRQOL) of CRs and CGs. Thus, this study will evaluate the effect of the standard RDAD among lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) CRs with AD/RD and their CGs, and this study will test a personalized intervention tailored to better respond to distinct risks experienced by CGs and LGBT CRs with AD/RD, addressing unique sexual/gender minority CG risk factors (e.g., identity management, stigma-related adverse or traumatic life events, and lack of social support).
description_detailed:
We will address the following aims:

Aim 1. Test the translation and enhancement of intervention designed to increase physical activities of older adult care receivers (CRs) with AD/RD and their CGs. Aim 2. Evaluate the short- and long-term effect of the standard and personalized intervention on primary (physical activity and functioning; perceived stress for CGs; independence/residential status (institutionalization) for CRs) and secondary outcomes (HRQOL; depressive symptomatology; behavioral disturbances for CRs). Aim 3. Test the moderating roles of CR-CG characteristics, including type of CR-CG relationship, sex, and severity of CR AD/RD, on the treatment effect of the standard and personalized intervention.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: A total of 161 dyad pairs (i.e., a person with dementia and their care partner) were enrolled and randomly assigned to either the personalized or standard arm.
participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: Participants recruited from multiple sources using a multifaceted approach, including direct referrals from community agencies providing aging and health services using presentations, flyers, newsletters, and social media.

groups.title: Personalized Intervention
groups.description:
Innovations in Dementia Empowerment and Action (IDEA):

9 60-minute virtual sessions for 6 weeks and 4 15-minute follow-up phone sessions for 4 months

Innovations in Dementia Empowerment and Action (IDEA): The IDEA intervention has the same exposure to treatment as the RDAD intervention. The behavioral component of the treatment manual is adapted to incorporate 3 risk factors that are empirically known to affect midlife and older lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) populations.These include: 1) identity management; 2) stigma-related adverse/traumatic life events; and 3) lack of social support. All other aspects of the treatment are preserved.

groups.title: Standard Intervention
groups.description:
Reducing Disabilities in Alzheimer's Disease (RDAD):

9 60-minute virtual sessions for 6 weeks and 4 15-minute follow-up phone sessions for 4 months

Reducing Disabilities in Alzheimer's Disease (RDAD): The RDAD intervention includes behavioral management training for caregiver and activities and exercise training for caregiver and care receiver.

achievements.comment: A dyad consists of a care recipient with dementia and their care partner. The personalized arm enrolled 81 dyads, resulting in 162 participants.
A dyad consists of a care recipient with dementia and their care partner. The personalized arm enrolled 80 dyads, resulting in 160 participants.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Physical Activity of Care Recipient
outcomeMeasures.description: Measured by the days of aerobic activity for at least 30 minutes in the past week with higher numbers indicating more days of activity.

outcomeMeasures.title: Depression of Care Partner: Center for Epidemiological Studies-Depression Scale (CESD-10)
outcomeMeasures.description: Assessed using the summed score on the 10-item Center for Epidemiological Studies-Depression Scale (CESD-10). Range of scores 0-27 with higher scores indicating higher levels of depression.

outcomeMeasures.title: Quality of Life in Alzheimer's Disease, Care Recipient
outcomeMeasures.description: Quality of life was evaluated using the summed score of the Quality of Life in Alzheimer's Disease (QOL-AD), a 13-item measure. Range of scores 13-52 with higher scores equal better quality of life.

outcomeMeasures.title: Memory-Related Disturbance, Care Recipient
outcomeMeasures.description: Assessed using mean scores on the memory-related subscale (7 items) of the 24-item Revised Memory and Behavior Problem Checklist (RMBPC). Ranges 0 -3. Higher scores indicate higher memory-related behavioral disturbances.

outcomeMeasures.title: Physical Functioning of Care Recipient: Medical Outcomes Study 36-Item Short Form (SF-36)
outcomeMeasures.description: Physical functioning was assessed using the mean score of the Physical Functioning subscale of the Medical Outcomes Study 36-Item Short Form (SF-36), consisting of 10 items asking about degree to which health status limits activities including walking, climbing, lifting, and bathing or dressing oneself. The summary score ranges from 0 to 100. Higher scores indicate higher physical functioning.

outcomeMeasures.title: Perceived Stress of Care Partner
outcomeMeasures.description: Assessed with mean scores of the 4-item Perceived Stress Scale. The summary score ranges from 0 to 4. Higher scores indicate more stress.

eventGroups.title: Standard Intervention, Care Partner
eventGroups.description:
Reducing Disabilities in Alzheimer's Disease (RDAD): 9 60-minute virtual sessions for 6 weeks and 4 15-minute follow-up phone sessions for 4 months

Reducing Disabilities in Alzheimer's Disease (RDAD): The RDAD intervention includes behavioral management training for caregiver and activities and exercise training for caregiver and care receiver.

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention described (RDAD: Reducing Disability in Alzheimer’s Disease) is a non-pharmacologic, dyadic program combining an exercise regimen for the person with dementia and caregiver training in behavioral-management techniques to reduce behavioral problems, caregiver stress, and functional decline. This original RDAD randomized trial showed improved physical activity, reduced depression/behavioral problems, and delayed institutionalization — it is not a drug targeting AD pathology. citeturn0search0turn0search2

Act: The described study (Aging With Pride: Innovations in Dementia Empowerment and Action / IDEA) adapts RDAD for sexual/gender minority (LGBT/SGM) older adults and their caregivers, testing a culturally tailored, personalized behavioral intervention (virtual and in-person coaching, exercises, caregiver strategies) rather than any biologic or small-molecule therapy. Key project descriptions and the IDEA adaptation paper confirm this approach. citeturn0search1turn0search5turn0search4

Reflect: By the provided category definitions, this trial does not test a biologic (monoclonal antibody/vaccine) or a small molecule aimed at Alzheimer pathology, nor a pharmacologic cognitive enhancer. Its primary mechanisms are behavioral management of neuropsychiatric/behavioral symptoms and caregiver support (plus exercise to improve function), which best map to the 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement' category. There is no drug or placebo used in the described intervention. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Web search results used to verify and support the above: JAMA report of the original RDAD randomized controlled trial (exercise + caregiver behavioral management). citeturn0search0; PubMed summary of the RDAD RCT. citeturn0search2; University of Washington / Aging with Pride: IDEA project description explaining the RDAD-based, culturally tailored intervention for LGBTQ older adults. citeturn0search1turn0search4; PubMed article describing the virtual adaptation and design of IDEA. citeturn0search5
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial (Aging With Pride: IDEA) adapts the RDAD program, a non-pharmacologic, dyadic intervention combining caregiver behavioral-management training and low-impact exercise for the person with dementia. It does not test a biologic, small molecule, antibody, vaccine, or other agent that targets AD pathology or a specific molecular pathway; instead it targets behavioral symptoms, caregiver skills, and physical activity. citeturn0search1turn0search6

Act: The intervention is described as a culturally tailored behavioral/caregiver coaching program (RDAD-based) delivered in-person or virtually, with exercises and caregiver strategies rather than any drug or biologic. Key project descriptions and the IDEA design paper confirm this non-pharmacologic approach. Therefore the study does not map to any CADRO biological target category (A–Q, R) and should be classified as 'Other'. citeturn0search0turn0search2turn0search3

Reflect: The classification was checked against CADRO categories: the trial does not target amyloid, tau, ApoE/lipids, inflammation, synaptic plasticity, metabolism, vasculature, etc., nor does it test a multi-target pharmacologic agent. Because it is a behavioral intervention aimed at neuropsychiatric symptom management and caregiver support (non-drug), 'T) Other' is the appropriate CADRO-aligned choice. If future information showed an embedded pharmacologic component, reclassification would be needed. citeturn0search4turn0search5
Web search results supporting this classification (key sources):
- 'Exercise Plus Behavioral Management in Patients With Alzheimer Disease' (RDAD randomized controlled trial, JAMA). citeturn0search1turn0search6
- University of Washington / Aging with Pride: IDEA project description (IDEA adapts RDAD for LGBTQ older adults). citeturn0search0turn0search2
- PubMed article on the virtual adaptation and design of IDEA. citeturn0search3
